title: HINT: Hierarchical Interaction Network for Clinical Trial Outcome Prediction

sections.input embedding module:
In this section, we describe the raw data and input representation learning.
Raw data used for trial outcome prediction come from three different sources, namely (1) drug molecules, (2) disease information and (3) trial protocols. 1. Drug molecules are important for predicting trial outcomes. The drug molecules are represented by SMILES strings or molecule graphs. There are many existing works in embedding drug molecules into latent vectors including knowledge base approach such as Morgan fingerprint and its variantsÂ , or representation learning methods for SMILES stringsÂ [ref]43 and molecule graphsÂ    .
HINT supports all three types of molecule embeddings. Formally, we represent all molecules ğ•„={m1,â‹¯,mNm}ğ•„subscriptğ‘š1â‹¯subscriptğ‘šsubscriptğ‘ğ‘š\mathbb{M}=\{m_{1},\cdots,m_{N_{m}}\} as drug (molecule) embedding where fmâ€‹(â‹…)subscriptğ‘“ğ‘šâ‹…f_{m}(\cdot) is the molecule embedding function and we average all molecule embeddings from a trial to get the drug embedding vector.
Our experiments show that average is a better aggregation function than summation for drug embedding.
The molecule embedding function fmsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘šf_{m} can be any of the above drug embedding methods. HINT supports Morgan fingerprintÂ , SMILES encoderÂ [ref]43, graph message passing neural network (MPNN)Â 6  for creating the drug embedding. 2. Disease information can also affect the trial outcome.
For example, drugs in oncology have much lower approval rate than ones in infectious diseasesÂ .
The disease information comes from its description and its corresponding ontology such as disease hierarchies like International Classification of Diseases (ICD)Â . Formally, we represent all diseases ğ”»={d1,â‹¯,dNd}ğ”»subscriptğ‘‘1â‹¯subscriptğ‘‘subscriptğ‘ğ‘‘\mathbb{D}=\{d_{1},\cdots,d_{N_{d}}\} (Eq.Â 2) as disease embedding, where GRAMâ€‹(di)GRAMsubscriptğ‘‘ğ‘–\text{GRAM}(d_{i}) represent an embedding of disease disubscriptğ‘‘ğ‘–d_{i} using GRAM (graph-based attention model)Â .
GRAM is designed to leverage the hierarchical information inherent to medical ontologies and succesfully used in predictive phenotypingÂ  [ref]18. Specifically, the representation of current disease disubscriptğ‘‘ğ‘–d_{i} is a convex combination of the basic embeddings (ğâˆˆâ„dğsuperscriptâ„ğ‘‘\mathbf{e}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}) of itself and its ancestors, i.e, where Î±jâ€‹iâˆˆâ„+subscriptğ›¼ğ‘—ğ‘–subscriptâ„\alpha_{ji}\in\mathbb{R}_{+} represents the attention weight and we have where g1â€‹(â‹…)subscriptğ‘”1â‹…g_{1}(\cdot) is a feed-forward network with a single hidden layer, followingÂ . Ancestorsâ€‹(i)Ancestorsğ‘–\text{Ancestors}(i) represents the set of all the ancestors of iğ‘–i.
An ancestor of code represent a higher-level category of the current code.
For example, in ICD 10 codeÂ , â€œD41â€ (urinary organs neoplasm) and â€œD41.2â€ (ureter neoplasm) are the ancestors of â€œD41.20â€ (right ureter neoplasm).
â€œC34â€ (malignant neoplasm of bronchus and lung) and â€œC34.9â€ (malignant neoplasm of unspecified part of bronchus or lung) are the ancestors of â€œC34.91â€ (malignant neoplasm of unspecified part of right bronchus or lung). 3. Trial protocol is a document that describes how a clinical trial will be conducted, includes eligibility criteria, which describes the patient recruitment requirements.
Eligibility criteria contain both inclusion and exclusion criteria denoted by Eq.Â (3), where ğœiIsubscriptsuperscriptğœğ¼ğ‘–{\bm{\mathbf{c}}}^{I}_{i} and ğœjEsubscriptsuperscriptğœğ¸ğ‘—{\bm{\mathbf{c}}}^{E}_{j} denote the iğ‘–i-th and jğ‘—j-th sentence in inclusion and exclusion criteria, respectively. To convert the criteria sentences into embedding vectors, we apply
Clinical-BERTÂ  5 which is a domain-specific version of BERTÂ . Then we use 4 one-dimensional convolutional layersÂ  0 (denoted Conv1d) with different kernel sizes (k1,â‹¯,k4subscriptğ‘˜1â‹¯subscriptğ‘˜4k_{1},\cdots,k_{4}) to capture semantics at 4 different granularity level.
